subject: probability
title: Multivariate Normal Distribution
contentHtml: In probability theory, a multivariate normal distribution is a joint distribution of multiple random variables that are normally distributed.

problem.statementHtml: Given a multivariate normal distribution with mean vector \(\mu\) and covariance matrix \(\Sigma\), find the marginal distribution of each variable.
hints: Hint: Use the properties of the multivariate normal distribution.
problem.solutionHtml: To find the marginal distribution, we can integrate out the other variables using the property that the marginal distribution is a normal distribution with mean and variance given by the corresponding elements of \(\mu\) and \(\Sigma\), respectively.
problem.answerShort: The marginal distribution is also normal

workedExample.problemHtml: Suppose we have two normally distributed random variables, \(x_1\) and \(x_2\), with mean vector \((\mu_1, \mu_2)\) and covariance matrix \([[\sigma_{11}, \sigma_{12}], [\sigma_{21}, \sigma_{22}]]\). Find the marginal distribution of each variable.

steps.explanation: The mean vector is given by the input parameters.
The covariance matrix is also given by the input parameters.

workedExample.finalAnswer: The marginal distribution of each variable is normal with mean and variance given by the corresponding elements of \(\mu\) and \(\Sigma\), respectively.

intuition: The multivariate normal distribution is a powerful tool for modeling complex systems, as it allows us to capture correlations between variables.

problem.statementHtml: Given a multivariate normal distribution with mean vector μ and covariance matrix Σ, find the marginal distribution of the i-th component.
hints: Hint: Use the properties of the multivariate normal distribution
problem.solutionHtml: To find the marginal distribution, we can use the fact that each component is normally distributed with mean μ_i and variance Σ_{ii}. Then, we can apply the univariate normal distribution formula.
problem.answerShort: The marginal distribution is a univariate normal distribution

workedExample.problemHtml: Suppose we have a multivariate normal distribution with mean vector (2, 3) and covariance matrix \[\left( \begin{array}{cc} 1 & 0.5 \\ 0.5 & 2 \end{array} \right) \]. Find the marginal distribution of the first component.

steps.description: Recognize that each component is normally distributed
steps.explanation: This allows us to apply the univariate normal distribution formula

steps.description: Find the mean and variance of the first component
steps.explanation: The mean is simply the corresponding element in the mean vector, while the variance can be found by looking at the covariance matrix

steps.description: Apply the univariate normal distribution formula
steps.explanation: This gives us the marginal distribution of the first component

workedExample.finalAnswer: The marginal distribution is a univariate normal distribution with mean 2 and variance 1.25

intuition: The multivariate normal distribution allows us to model complex systems by specifying the relationships between multiple variables.

name: Multivariate Normal Distribution" },
statementHtml: Let \(x_1, x_2, x_3\) be a random vector following the multivariate normal distribution with mean vector \(\mu = (2, 3, 4)\) and covariance matrix \(\Sigma = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0.5 & 0.2 \\ 0.5 & 2 & 0.8 \\ 0.2 & 0.8 & 3 \end{bmatrix}\).
hints: Hint: Start by finding the marginal distributions
solutionHtml:
To find the marginal distribution of \\(x_1\\), we can integrate out \\(x_2\\) and \\(x_3\\) from the joint density.

  • Find the mean vector: \\(\\mu = (2, 3, 4)\\)
  • Finding the marginal distribution of \\(x_1\\): \\[ f(x_1) = \\frac{1}{\sqrt{(2\\pi)^3 |\\Sigma|}} \exp\\left(-\\frac{1}{2} (x_1 - \\mu_1)^T \\Sigma^{-1} (x_1 - \\mu_1) \\right] \\]
",
answerShort: The marginal distribution of \\(x_1\\) is a normal distribution with mean 2 and variance 1.5" },
